answers.answer: I am not seeing any 90 or 100%. 70 and 80% is questionable.  There are some really good cholesterol medications out there.  Also, there is an option of stents.  Open heart surgery carries a 1 in 5 of dying.  She is young, so she has that going for her.  In the near future, there is a lot of new procedures coming out.  Heart surgeries will no longer be open heart according to the heart surgeons I spoke with.  Unless there is some reason why they cannot do stents.  Talk to your doctor and possibly get a second opinion so that you feel comfortable that you are making the correct choice.

The American College of Cardiology have guidelines to follow.  Medication is appropriate for CAD if there is relief from any angina (indicates the coronary arteries dilate sufficiently to provide oxygenated blood to the heart cells).Almost always an occlusion less than 70% doesn't require intervention or medication.If medication (some people can't tolerate) does not provide sufficient supply and there is angina, then a stent would be appropriate.  Sometimes a stent isn't an option due to location of the lesion, size, and an emergency.  Then CABG (bypass)..QUOTE: ".The area of the LAD shows 80% discrete stenosis at its ostium.... and LCx: shows plaque at its ostium..."  may be a location that can't be stented.  The LAD and LCx branch off the main coronary artery, and at the junction (the ostium of LAD and LCx) would be difficult to stent as stenting one vessel crowds out the lumen of the other vessel.  I don't believe the technology provides a "Y" stent!?The other lesions should not be a problem and with proper diet, exercise, lipid levels controlled, etc. there may not be any progression with medication.  I have a totally blocked LAD (collateral vessels provide a natural bypass) and LCx is 72% blocked.  I have been successfully treated for 5 years with medication and feel well.Talk to a non-inverventional cardiologist.  CABG should be the last resort.
If we decide not to go for bypass what will be the risk involved?

Risks are higher fior individuals with following:Age -- patients over 70 are at a slightly higher risk for complicationsGender -- women have a slightly higher riskHaving another serious medical condition (such as diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, kidney disease, or lung disease)Previous heart surgery -- puts a person at a higher riskPossible risks include: Blood clots; Death (very small risk); Heart attackSternal wound infection (this complication most often occurs with obesity, diabetes, or having had previous CABG); Stroke (the risk is greatest in those over 70).About a third of patients have "post-pericardiotomy syndrome" a few days to 6 months after surgery. The symptoms of this syndrome are fever and chest pain. It can be treated with medication. The surgery site in the chest or the graft site (if the graft was from the leg or arm) can be itchy, sore, numb, or bruised. Some people report memory loss and loss of mental clarity or "fuzzy thinking" after CABG.
